Award.AwardTitle: Noyce Teacher Leaders for Western Kansas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Noyce Teacher-Leaders for Western Kansas project is developing STEM teachers for rural communities. STEM teachers in a rural western Kansas school are frequently considered the science and mathematics expert in both the school system and the community. Therefore, the project is not only developing quality STEM teachers who are providing needed services to small size communities, such as teaching AP or distance courses, but also developing quality leaders for communities. Through a dual degree program, in addition to completing the requirements for a STEM major at Fort Hays State University (FHSU), the Noyce Teacher-Leaders also complete an education degree, allowing these students to be highly qualified teachers within their discipline. They are being prepared to teach in a rural setting, teach Advanced Placement courses, and deliver distance education. Noyce Teacher-Leaders are also engaged in field experiences in rural high-needs districts. The project provides critically needed support for 18 future STEM teachers during their junior and senior years and resources to recruit freshmen and sophomore STEM students through participation in informal summer science and mathematics camps (6 each in summers 1-4). Mentoring and professional development opportunities support Noyce Teacher-Leaders in remote rural areas. The project offers a model for recruitment, retention and preparation of STEM teachers working in rural districts. The model has broad impact on the region because with good teacher-leaders comes the reward of a new generation of students with interests in STEM fields. The major intellectual merit is in the model for identifying and developing critical thinking skills, attributes, and characteristics for STEM educators in high needs rural districts and a model for building sustainable partnerships over a large geographic region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Noyce Teacher Leaders for Western Kansas NSF Noyce Scholarship Program (DUE 1239991) has been very successful with respect to its primary goals of recruiting students to become STEM teachers and retaining them in the field, even after their service period expired. During the 4 years before the Noyce Program began here at Fort Hays State University (FHSU), there was an average of 4.5 STEM education graduates per year. However, during the 6 year cycle of our Noyce program, FHSU has averaged 9.5 STEM education graduates per year. This increase certainly is highly correlated with the scholarship dollars received by the students, but is also due to the fact that many value-added experiences have not only initially attracted students, but have helped retain them in the field to this day.

With respect to recruiting, FHSU adopted a multi-pronged approach during the grant cycle. In addition to recruiting promising on-campus STEM students who may have an interest in teaching, we recruited students from area community colleges as well as freshmen and sophomore students through our Summer Scholar Program. The interest in transfer students coming to FHSU to complete their STEM education degree was unexpected, but has allowed FHSU to develop Articulation Agreements with 5 area community colleges for seamless transfer into our STEM education program. In addition, we now have identified a primary liaison (a science or math professor/instructor) within each of these schools who informs students about the opportunities available to their students at FHSU. This direct line of contact between the institutions has proven beneficial many times over.

The Summer Scholar program has also been a fruitful avenue for producing Noyce Scholars at FHSU. The program hires students to work with faculty or professionals to conduct summer STEM day camps for elementary and middle-school aged children. These students may initially be helping with regular tasks, but by the end of the 4 weeks of summer camps are often teaching part of the camp. This experience has provided students with an internship-like opportunity to explore education as a career, and has helped solidify some students’ decisions to become teachers, while others have decided to stay within their STEM program. Either way, we view the program as a success, as students are more confident about their career path choice.

Another key statistic is that of the 28 students received scholarship dollars from the Noyce Program (some for 1 year and some for 2 years), 25 of them are either currently teaching in a STEM discipline, student-teaching in a STEM discipline, or still on track to complete their STEM education degree. Only 2 voluntarily left the program after 1 semester, and 1 is deceased. In addition, of all the students who are currently teaching in the field, all have continued to teach Science or Math even after their service period expired, with most of them still in the same high-needs school they started, or having moved to another high-needs school.

This level of retention can be attributed to many value-added experiences the students received during their time as a Noyce scholar. Each Noyce scholar was required to attend a weekly seminar course which focused primarily on teaching in rural schools (since that is our primary service area and the region from which many of our students originate). Research shows that many students who enter teaching in a rural area will leave after only a few years due to factors such as professional isolation (they may be the only math/science teacher in their building or district), and stress of time management (teaching as many as 6 distinct preparations per day as well as helping with after-school activities such as coaching), among other factors. Despite their familiarity with rural areas of the state, many students still need guidance in these areas, and we believe the seminar course has been very helpful to maintain students within teaching. Other value-added experiences included travel to state, regional, and national math/science conferences; helping students to begin to build a network of professionals for advice, and a weeklong Rural Field Experience which has allowed the pre-service teachers the opportunity to help within a real-live classroom in a rural area.

Finally, FHSU has been very active in trying to secure funds to continue to partner with our current in-service Noyce teachers to help them become Teacher Leaders within their community. Three were able to attend a NASA workshop in Orlando, and seven more will be attending a PBL workshop at the Dodge City Weather Station in May.

We have thoroughly enjoyed our work in this grant, and look forward to the contributions this new cohort of teachers will bring to their students and to the STEM education community.
